header.title: Invocation to Our Lady of Midnight, Liliya-Devala, Being a Conjuration of the High Sabbatic Witch- Mother

central_thesis: This text provides a detailed ceremonial invocation for summoning Liliya-Devala, the Sovereign Witch-Mother of the Sabbatic Craft, into a chosen female officiant (Magistra) to facilitate direct spiritual communion, oracle-giving, and guidance for the assembled covine. It emphasizes her role as a primary deity, co-regent with Mahazhael-Deval, within the tradition's unique cosmology and operative practices.

structure_content.summary: The introduction contextualizes the ritual within the Sabbatic Craft, highlighting its purpose: to allow a female officiant to become a 'vessel' for Liliya-Devala's spirit. It notes the importance of prior knowledge from the 'Invocation of Mahazhael-Deval' and the concept of dual-observance, establishing Liliya-Devala as the counterpoint to the Witch-Father Mahazhael-Deval.

This section delves into Liliya-Devala's cosmological significance. She is revered as Queen of the Sixteen Faithful Gods, Warden of the Northern Quarter, Lunar Mother, and co-regent with Mahazhael-Deval. The text explores her syncretic identifications with the Virgin Mary (as Queen of the World and walker of the Crooked Path) and Mary Magdalene (secret bride of the Crucified King), emphasizing her chthonic and lunar aspects and her role as a divine progenitor.

This core operative section contains the invocation proper. It begins with the Magistra bearing a skull mask and the covine calling to Liliya. The invocation describes her dual nature ('twain of mask and face'), her sacred implements (blood-red rope, scythe, skull-cup of nectar, mortar of perfumed embers), her hidden hands that turn the Wheel of the Stars, and her symbolic form (shadow-spreading wings, talons of the screeching owl).

Following the invocation, the text details the symbolic offerings to Liliya, which are presented as 'imaginal projection or mental sacrifice' by the covine. These offerings include potent archetypal images and substances, meant to deepen the connection and affirm devotion. This is followed by ritual instructions for genuflections, the Magistra's transformation into a vessel, circumambulation, and the delivery of the oracle.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Oracle and Riddle of Liliya
structure_content.summary: This final phase describes the Magistra's full possession by Liliya-Devala, signaled by a blood-red cowl and skull mask. The Magistra then performs a widdershins circumambulation, offering blessings and receiving petitions. Upon returning to the North, she delivers Liliya's Oracles, culminating in the 'Riddle of Liliya,' a seven-day cycle narrative that encapsulates her mystery, wisdom, and the 'Mystery of the Wine'.

key_concepts.definition: The Sovereign Witch-Mother, Queen of the Sixteen Faithful Gods, Warden of the Northern Quarter, Lunar Mother, and Begetter of the Earthen Child within the Sabbatic Craft. She embodies dual aspects ('twain of mask and face') and is identified with both generative and destructive forces, syncretized with the Virgin Mary and Mary Magdalene.
The chosen female officiant who serves as the 'Oracle and Magical Vehicle' for Liliya-Devala during the invocation. She undergoes a ritual transformation to embody the spirit of the Witch-Mother.
The assembled group of practitioners participating in the ritual, who collectively call upon Liliya-Devala and receive her blessings and guidance through the Magistra.
The pantheon revered in the Sabbatic Craft, comprising eight witch-fathers and eight witch-mothers, over whom Liliya-Devala and Mahazhael-Deval reign as Queen and King, respectively.

key_concepts.term: Crooked Path of the Dragon's Spine
key_concepts.definition: A symbolic spiritual and magical path of gnosis, associated with Liliya-Devala and represented by her standing on the Red Serpent, signifying mastery over primordial forces and unconventional wisdom.

A primary ritual implement, flower-wreathed, borne by the Magistra during the invocation. It symbolizes Liliya-Devala's aspect as the 'Boneward' and her dominion over life and death, serving as a conduit for her presence and blessings.
The non-physical offerings made by the covine, consisting of potent symbolic images and concepts 'wrought in our mind' rather than tangible objects, presented upon an 'altar-bed of bones'.

A prophetic narrative or 'Arcanum' spoken by the Magistra when fully possessed by Liliya-Devala. It describes a seven-day cycle embodying the Witch-Mother's transformative powers, cycles of being, and the 'Mystery of the Wine'.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined is a structured ceremonial invocation, executed by a covine under the guidance of a Magistra. Its primary objective is the temporary embodiment of Liliya-Devala's spirit within the Magistra, enabling direct communication, receipt of oracles, and the bestowal of blessings or guidance. The ritual involves specific spatial orientations, verbal invocations, symbolic offerings, and a transformative process for the officiant, culminating in a prophetic delivery.
tools: Flower-wreathed skull (borne by Magistra as mask)
Blood-red cloth (used as hooded cowl for Magistra)
Candles (lit in the Northern Quarter for adoration)
Divers effigies of the Lady (optional, placed in Northern Quarter)
Imaginal Offerings (e.g., earth-sign in flames, empty crib, jackals, virgin-child, bloodied flower, spilt semen, corpse-candle)
rituals: Preparation: Review 'Invocation of Mahazhael-Deval' for context; understand dual-observance and the Sixteen Faithful Gods.
Magistra's Initial Stance: Stands silently in the North, bearing a flower-wreathed skull as the mask of the Lady.
Covine's Call: The assembled covine chants the specific invocation to Liliya-Devala, proclaiming her nature and titles.

Offerings: The covine kneels to offer 'imaginal projections or mental sacrifices' upon an 'altar-bed of bones.' These include an earth-sign in flames, an empty crib, savage jackals, a virgin-child, a bloodied flower, spilt semen, and a corpse-candle.
Genuflections and Spirit Influx: Genuflections are made to the 'Place of Power' while uttering the mantic call 'Kha-l-Liliya' until the Officiant is filled with Liliya's spirit.
Magistra's Transformation: As a sign of possession, the Officiant places a blood-red cloth as a hooded cowl over her head and continues bearing the skull as a mask.

Circumambulation and Interaction: The Magistra walks the circle 'against the Sun' (widdershins). She stops before each initiate, inclining the skull for its 'lips' to kiss them, allowing each to ask for guidance, blessings, and vision.
Oracle Delivery: Upon returning North, the Magistra appoints the skull to its place, then turns to the covine to speak Liliya's Oracles, including the 'Riddle of Liliya' and other guidance.
Concluding Affirmation: The ritual concludes with the collective affirmation: 'As it is spoken, so mote it be! Bilo Bilo Hu! Bha-Azha-Ka!'

relevant_quotes.text: Through the successful exaction of this ritual, the female officiant (or Magistra) will become the Oracle and Magical Vehicle for the very presence of the Initiatrix, and the covine will thus be honoured with her direct blessing and will be able to entreat Her face-to-face for guidance and augury.
O' Liliya! Hear us! Sovereign Blood-Mother of the Horned Serpent's Wisdom! Our blessing and our curse upon Thee, for Thou art twain of mask and face!

In Thy four outstretched hands are the signs of Thy dominion. In Thine upper left hand is a blood-red rope of execution- A plaited noose which Thou hast woven with the stolen birthcords of man. In Thine upper right hand is a scythe, as sharp as the blackthorne in winter. In Thy lower left hand is a skull-cup, overflowing with golden nectar. In Thy lower right hand is a mortar of black obsidian filled with perfumed embers, bestrewing field and furrow with the fiery seed of the Midwinter pyre.

Hear my tale spun on the circle, hear ye the Thorn-queen's Riddle! For with one step the world is begun and with the next all things are done. 'On the first day I slept beneath the black sickle. On the second day I knelt in prayer 'neath the moon. On the third day I spread wide in full flower. On the fourth day my body was heavy with burden. On the fifth day my fruit lay in the cradle of harvest. On the sixth day the flesh was barren of blood. On the seventh day I was raised anew to fill the cuo of salutation, To serve at the Round Feast for both the Living and the Dead! 'The Mystery of the Wine' is my Name of my Name, the Mother of Wise-blood am I. May the Blessing be and the Cursing be upon all who come to drink of me!'

critical_analysis.relevance: This invocation is a seminal work within the Traditional Witchcraft current, specifically the Cultus Sabbati, founded by Andrew D. Chumbley. It provides a rare, explicit, and operative glimpse into the sophisticated cosmology, deity veneration, and ritual mechanics of this highly influential, yet often esoteric, magical tradition. Its focus on direct gnosis through deity possession and the synthesis of chthonic, lunar, and gnostic themes offers a significant contribution to modern occult studies, demonstrating a lineage-specific approach to spirit work distinct from many ceremonial magic traditions. The text's syncretism and symbolic richness invite deep study and comparative analysis within the broader Western Esoteric tradition.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Advanced practitioners of Traditional Witchcraft, particularly those engaged with or studying the works of Andrew D. Chumbley and the Cultus Sabbati. It presupposes familiarity with foundational concepts of Sabbatic Gnosis, the broader pantheon, and the specific ritual dynamics of this tradition. It is not intended for beginners due to its complex symbolism, advanced ritual requirements, and the profound nature of deity possession described.
